messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?Reply
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: No, the images you attached are all photographs of well known and often illustrated Nobuiye. Akiyama, who died in 1936, was the foremost researcher on
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
No, the images you attached are all photographs of well known and often
illustrated Nobuiye. Akiyama, who died in 1936, was the foremost
researcher on tsuba, particularly iron. of his day, and has left a
lasting impression on the categorization of tsuba to this day. He
collected dozens and dozens of oshigata of Nobuiye, some very
unassuming, as was the found one I refereed to, and they were published
by a Mr. Nakayama, or Nakamura or something close to that (only my poor
brain as a reference here). When you see one like the example you asked
about, what makes me suspicious is the "pulled out of the fire" look it
has and the lack of depth and sharpness to the chisel work. Those done
by the Norisuke, I and II, often look quite good, but they must be
examined in hand. They often are deficient on the part of the mimi you
don't see from a photograph, as it is said they tended to work from
books that did not illustrate the sides, or that is one story I have
heard.
There are many many gimei Owari Nobuiye out there as his work was very
much in vogue during the early 19th Cent. revival period. One the other
hand there were other, entirely legitimate Nobuiye working elsewhere,
and they are entirely worthy collectors' pieces in many cases.
The dealer, that should probably remain confidential to him.
I hope this helps.
Arnold




>>> matthewhoyle@... 01/31/05 4:41 PM >>>

Hi Arnold, thanks for the response. Did you mean the book that these
scans
came from? http://www.jpsword.com/files/kn/nobuiye.html
This webpage is very good for making side by side comparisons with the
pix
on Mr. Weissberg's website. I think I can see the sutble differences in
the
mei now, or perhaps I want to believe I can *grin*. Some more pointers
in
this direction might be good for me all the same. Are there any
specifics to
look for besides the 'softness'?

With regards to the Akiyama tsuba that was found, the mind boggles how
it
wound up on a table at a sword show in the US among a pile of other
tsuba!

Matt

Ps. I know I shouldn't ask, but who was the lucky finder?

From: "arnold frenzel" <afrenzel@...><~!B*+R^&>To:

Monday, January 31, 2005 7:05 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?


>
> Hi:
> At first glance it does look rather nice, however the mei looks
> tentative, soft and not quite right to me. The first thing one would
> what to do is to consult the book of Akiyama collected Nobuiye (title
> escapes me without reference material here) which illustrates the vast
> bulk of know Nobuiye out there. A few years ago a well known
California
> dealer was lucky enough to find one at a show, bought it and it
> eventually went Juyo. Sure enough is found among the Akiyama oshigata.
> You can be quite sure that if such a tsuba left Japan and were correct
> the price would have at least another zero on the end, and probably an
> initial digit change as well.
> Arnold
>
>
> >>> matthewhoyle@... 01/30/05 5:32 PM >>>
>
> Gimei Nobuiye?
>
> http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html
>

> tell?
> It looks awfully similar to the ones in the books!
>
> And if it is indeed gimei, how old is it do we think?
>
> Matt
